title: 115_hr1783
content: The Act titled "Improving Veterans Access to Quality Care Act of 2017" expands the availability of prosthetic and orthotic care for veterans. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will work with higher education institutions to establish or expand advanced degree programs in prosthetics and orthotics to enhance care for veterans. A report outlining the plan for this initiative must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year. The Department of Veterans Affairs will consult with various organizations to develop a plan for advanced degree programs in prosthetics and orthotics. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2017 for this initiative, with funds available until September 30, 2020. This section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. PROVISION OF FULL PRACTICE AUTHORITY FOR ADVANCED PRACTICE REGISTERED NURSES, PHYSICIAN ASSISTANTS, AND OTHER HEALTH CARE PROFESSIONALS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will grant full practice authority to advanced practice registered nurses, physician assistants, and other licensed health care professionals within the Department of Veterans Affairs, regardless of any state limitations on their practice. The term "advanced practice registered nurse" is defined in section 5509(e)(1) of Public Law 111-148. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will grant full practice authority to advanced practice registered nurses and physician assistants, allowing them to practice within the Department of Veterans Affairs without state limitations. Full practice authority means the full scope of practice for the area of nursing or medicine as determined by the respective national professional associations or organizations. The term "physician assistant" is defined in the Social Security Act. Transfer of health care provider credentialing data from Secretary of Defense to Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Defense must transfer credentialing data of covered health care providers to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs upon request. Covered providers are those who were employed by the Secretary of Defense, provided health care services, and were credentialed by the Secretary of Defense. Both Secretaries must establish policies and regulations for implementation. The section defines "credentialing" as the process of evaluating qualifications and credentials. It also states that regulations will be promulgated as necessary. This section will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act.
